importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and timeline of the Reefline project, which is a major environmental and cultural initiative in Miami Beach.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with construction and growth phases beginning in 2025 and extending through to at least 2035.

keyTakeAways: Miami Beach is creating a 7-mile-long artificial reef called Reefline, which will be located about 700 feet offshore and accessible to swimmers in shallow water (15 to 20 feet deep).
The project combines art and science, featuring marine-grade concrete sculptures, including 22 cars arranged in a traffic jam, and future elements like 57 giant starfish.
Coral nursery expert Colin Foord is involved in cultivating over 2,000 gorgonian soft corals, which will be transplanted onto the reef to restore and revive the natural coral ecosystem.

Artistic director Ximena Caminos, originally from Argentina, is a cultural placemaker who has used art to revitalize neighborhoods in Buenos Aires and Miami Beach, and she is spearheading the Reefline project as a public ecotourism and environmental restoration initiative.
The project is funded by a $5 million Miami Beach city bond approved by voters and aims to raise $6 million more for its first phase, which begins this month.
The reef is designed to restore what Miami Beach lost in the 1970s when sand was used to replenish the beach, smothering the original offshore coral reef.

The project includes an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs and aims to make underwater sculptures visible from the air, potentially becoming a symbol of the city.
Artist Leandro Ehrlich contributes to the project, believing that over time, coral growth will cover and transform the sculptures into living, natural habitats.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project — a 7-mile-long artificial reef extending offshore, combining marine art and coral restoration. Led by artistic director Ximena Caminos and coral expert Colin Foord, the project features 22 concrete cars and future elements like 57 giant starfish, designed to be transformed by growing coral. The reef, located 700 feet off shore and accessible to swimmers, aims to restore a coral habitat lost since the 1970s. It is funded by a $5 million city bond and a $6 million public fundraising campaign, with a timeline spanning at least a decade. The project includes a marine learning center to educate the public and seeks to become a symbol of ecological resilience and artistic innovation in Miami Beach.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
